title: 106_s3216
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" permits judicial review of binational panel determinations under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges misinterpretation of US law, panel misconduct, departure from procedure, or exceeding powers, review in the Court of International Trade is allowed. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel determinations under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act if the panel exceeds its powers or fails to apply the appropriate standard of review. Appeals can be filed with the United States Court of International Trade within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If a panel is not convened within 315 days of a request, the requesting party can seek review in court. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel determinations under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. Appeals can be filed with the United States Court of International Trade within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If a panel is not convened within 315 days of a request, the requesting party can seek review in court. The Court of International Trade will vacate the original panel decision and enter judgment accordingly. Decisions under this section are binding on the parties. If a panel is not convened, the court will review the investigating authority's determination for compliance with article 1904. The Court of International Trade will vacate the investigating authority's determination if it is not in accordance with article 1904 or lacks legal and factual support. Decisions made by the court are binding on the parties involved. If a party files a notice of appeal, the Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction to review the determination. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over determinations related to goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duties. Decisions made by the court are final and not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. The North American Free Trade Implementation Act is amended to reflect this jurisdiction. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over determinations related to goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duties. Decisions made by the court are final and not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. The North American Free Trade Implementation Act is amended to reflect this jurisdiction. Sec. 404A reviews binational panel determinations. Jurisdiction of the Court of International Trade is outlined in SEC. 3. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and investigating authorities under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and investigating authorities under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act, including a new provision for review requests under section 404A. The amendments made by this Act apply to goods from Canada and Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement. The effective date is determined by final decisions of binational panels or investigating authorities published in the Federal Register after the enactment of this Act.
